pullRequest.body:
Coxeter Systems and Coxeter Groups
---------------------------------------------------

This branch adds:

* `Matrix.IsCoxeter` :  A matrix `IsCoxeter` if it is a symmetric matrix with diagonal entries
  equal to one and off-diagonal entries distinct from one.
* `Matrix.CoxeterGroup` : The group defined by generators and relations according to a Coxeter matrix.
* `CoxeterSystem` : A structure recording the isomorphism between a group `W` and the group
  presentation corresponding to a Coxeter matrix, i.e. `Matrix.CoxeterGroup M`.
* `IsCoxeterGroup` : A group is a Coxeter group if it is registered in a Coxeter System.
---

In the basic API for Coxeter systems, I would think you could include this lemma:
```lean
@[simp]
lemma apply_mul_apply_pow (cs : CoxeterSystem M W) (b₁ b₂ : B) :
    (cs b₁ * cs b₂) ^ M b₁ b₂ = 1 := sorry
```

> In the basic API for Coxeter systems, I would think you could include this lemma:
> 
> ```lean
> @[simp]
> lemma apply_mul_apply_pow (cs : CoxeterSystem M W) (b₁ b₂ : B) :
>     (cs b₁ * cs b₂) ^ M b₁ b₂ = 1 := sorry
> ```

As the current PR is already getting rather large I would like to focus on getting what I have into Mathlib and then can add this in a future PR.

Bourbaki does not assume that `B` is finite.

We cannot make such a `HPow` assumption. There are different ways to take this into account, but in mathlib, the convention (see `GroupTheory.OrderOfElement`) is that the order of an element of infinite order is zero.
`CoxeterGroup` is a better name than `ToCoxeterPresentation`: `PresentedGroup` is a type, the type of elements in the group given by the presentation...
It seems that `CoxeterSystem` would be a better name.
I would think that this could be a typeclass (`class` instead of `def`), with three fields.

```suggestion
variable (M : Matrix B B ℕ)
```
In a Coxeter group, we may want to be able to state that the order of $s_i s_j$ is $M_{i, j}$ regardless whether the order is finite or not. Then, as in mathlib `orderOf` of an element of infinite order is `0`, I would suggest using `ℕ` instead of `ℕ∞`, but then the `off_diagonal` condition should be changed saying `M i j ≠ 1` instead, and a comment about this should be made in the docstring of `Matrix.IsCoxeter`.
Actually, I think `ℕ+` would be better, no?

Also, here  you say `M i j ≠ 1` but below in your other comment you have `off_diagonal : ∀ i j : B, i ≠ j → 2 ≤ M i j := by aesop`, so I am confused what you really are wanting here but I will assume it is the later as this allows the use of `aesop`.

I had two independant suggestions : 1) add `by aesop` 2) `M i j ≠ 1`.

Could you give a *detailed* explanation why `ℕ+` would be better?

Well if we were going to do a combination of `M i j ≠ 1` and `Nat`, then technically the identity matrix would be a Coxeter matrix, which isn't true.  That is, all diagonal elements would be equal to 1 and the off diagonal elements would not be equal to 1, which we don't want.  If we are going to go with `Nat` then I think we should keep the `off_diagonal : ∀ i j : B, i ≠ j → 2 ≤ M i j` as this doesn't allow the off diagonal elements to be zero.
Again, Bourbaki allows elements of infinite order (which in mathlib are considered of order `0`)...

```suggestion
variable {B}
```
The type `B` can be inferred automatically in the definition of `IsCoxeter`.

```suggestion
  symmetric : M.IsSymm := by aesop
  diagonal : ∀ i j : B, i = j → M i j = 1 := by aesop
  off_diagonal : ∀ i j : B, i ≠ j → 2 ≤ M i j := by aesop
```
Doing so, if the definitions are set up correctly, we do not need to provide any proof as lean will automatically try `aesop`.
Actually, `diagonal` should be `∀ i : B, M i i = 1`

> Doing so, if the definitions are set up correctly, we do not need to provide any proof as lean will automatically try `aesop`.

I am not sure what you mean by 'not providing any proof' but I assume you mean we wouldn't need to provide proofs for the `instance`s?  If so, maybe you can show me an example.

I wasn't able to prove `IsCoxeter` by using only `aesop` for the all the matrices I have.  I was able to find proofs, but `aesop` alone did not suffice.
I pushed what I currently have so at least you can see most of the changes you were mentioning above (except the `instance`s, c.f. above comment).

If we use  `ℕ` instead of `ℕ+`, for `A_n`, we only need the following code:
```lean
instance AₙIsCoxeter : IsCoxeter (Aₙ n) where
```

There is no need for auxiliary definitions here. I am not completely sure what is the mathlib practice for the definition of matrices, but if you do `abbrev Aₙ : Matrix (Fin n) (Fin n) ℕ := ...`, then the proof of `IsCoxeter` will be automatic. I think that `Aₙ` (better name `A`) should take `n` as an explicit parameter rather than an implicit one.
This should be an `instance`, not a `theorem`.
The relation is not right.
There should be `∃ B` in the condition.

I added the suggestions you had below in the branch I just pushed but in regards to the existential quantifiers, I think taking them out simplifies it as the class parameters will still require a proof of a correctly typed matrix to be supplied (but maybe there is a more desirable reason to require them that I am not foreseeing).  Do you still think they are needed?
`mulEquiv` and `ofMulEquiv` would be better names than `repr` and `ofRepr`.

The assumption `[M.IsCoxeter]` should be made here, or at the very least for the definition of `Matrix.CoxeterGroup`, because we do not want to consider the presented group `M.CoxeterGroup` unless we know that `M` satisfies the expected conditions.

When I tried adding it to those definitions in different combinations, non of them would pass the linter.  I was able to get it to pass the linter when adding `[M.IsCoxeter]` to both `CoxeterSystem` and `IsCoxeterGroup`.  Although this isn't as ideal as making the constraint on `Matrix.CoxeterGroup` it was the best that I was able to figure out where at least `CoxeterSystem` and `IsCoxeterGroup` both need the matrix to be a Coxeter matrix.

Do you know of another way of doing it better than this by adding `[M.IsCoxeter]` to the defintions somehow which would get past the linter?  After the code compiles and I save the file I do `lake build && lake exe runMathlibLinter Mathlib.GroupTheory.SpecificGroups.Coxeter` to run the linter.

This is a case where it is reasonable to circumvent the `unusedArguments` linter. I think you can do
```lean
@[nolint unusedArguments]
def ofMatrix [M.IsCoxeter] : B × B → FreeGroup B :=
```
and similarly for the other definitions which may require it.
I think we need the assumption `[NeZero n]` here.
After this definition, you should define `Matrix.coxeterSystemCoxeterGroup` which would say that there is a Coxeter system of type `M` on the group `M.CoxeterGroup` (with the identity isomorphism).
After this definition, you should provide a lemma in the `CoxeterSystem` namespace saying that the group is a Coxeter group, and also an instance saying that `M.CoxeterGroup` is a Coxeter group.

Can you remove the assumption `[M.IsCoxeter]` from this definition and the next ones, when it plays no role? Typically, in definitions, try to minimize the assumptions, and only put these in theorems.
It was suggested that I add this in a previous review.  See next comment below as well.

I said it was important to have the assumption `[M.IsCoxeter]` the definition of `Matrix.CoxeterGroup`, because we do not want to consider `M.CoxeterGroup` for a junk matrix. For the definitions in the section `CoxeterGroup.Relations`, it is more a matter of taste; you may certainly follow @sgouezel suggestion.

@joelriou and @sgouezel,  below are two different ways of possibly doing it as I am currently aware and with the suggestions I have been given.  Which one is preferred?

```lean
noncomputable section

variable {B : Type*} [DecidableEq B]

variable (M : Matrix B B ℕ)

/-- A matrix `IsCoxeter` if it is a symmetric matrix with diagonal entries equal to one
and off-diagonal entries distinct from one. -/
class Matrix.IsCoxeter (M : Matrix B B ℕ) : Prop where
  symmetric : M.IsSymm := by aesop
  diagonal : ∀ i : B, M i i = 1 := by aesop
  off_diagonal : ∀ i j : B, i ≠ j → M i j ≠ 1 := by aesop

/-- The group presentation corresponding to a Coxeter matrix. -/
@[nolint unusedArguments]
abbrev Matrix.CoxeterGroup [M.IsCoxeter] :=
  PresentedGroup <| Set.range <| Function.uncurry fun i j =>
    (FreeGroup.of i * FreeGroup.of j) ^ M i j

/-- A Coxeter system `CoxeterSystem W` is a structure recording the isomorphism between
a group `W` and the group presentation corresponding to a Coxeter matrix. Equivalently, this can
be seen as a list of generators of `W` parameterized by the underlying type of `M`, which
satisfy the relations of the Coxeter matrix `M`. -/
structure CoxeterSystem [M.IsCoxeter] (W : Type*) [Group W]  where
  /-- `CoxeterSystem.ofMulEquiv` constructs a Coxeter system given an equivalence with the group
  presentation corresponding to a Coxeter matrix `M`. -/
  ofMulEquiv ::
    /-- `mulEquiv` is the isomorphism between the group `W` and the group presentation
    corresponding to a Coxeter matrix `M`. -/
    mulEquiv : Matrix.CoxeterGroup M ≃* W

/-- Coxeter system of type `M` on the group `M.CoxeterGroup`. -/
def Matrix.coxeterSystemCoxeterGroup [M.IsCoxeter] : CoxeterSystem M M.CoxeterGroup :=
  CoxeterSystem.ofMulEquiv (MulEquiv.refl (CoxeterGroup M))

/-- A group is a Coxeter group if it is registered in a Coxeter system. -/
class IsCoxeterGroup [M.IsCoxeter] (W : Type*) [Group W] : Prop where
  nonempty_system : Nonempty (CoxeterSystem M W)

```
where I have squashed the relations into `Matrix.CoxeterGroup`.

Or

```lean
universe u

noncomputable section

variable {B : Type u} [DecidableEq B]

variable (M : Matrix B B ℕ)

/-- A matrix `IsCoxeter` if it is a symmetric matrix with diagonal entries equal to one
and off-diagonal entries distinct from one. -/
class Matrix.IsCoxeter : Prop where
  symmetric : M.IsSymm := by aesop
  diagonal : ∀ i : B, M i i = 1 := by aesop
  off_diagonal : ∀ i j : B, i ≠ j → M i j ≠ 1 := by aesop

/-- The group presentation corresponding to a Coxeter matrix. -/
abbrev Matrix.CoxeterGroup :=
  PresentedGroup <| Set.range <| Function.uncurry fun i j =>
    (FreeGroup.of i * FreeGroup.of j) ^ M i j

/-- A Coxeter system `CoxeterSystem W` is a structure recording the isomorphism between
a group `W` and the group presentation corresponding to a Coxeter matrix. Equivalently, this can
be seen as a list of generators of `W` parameterized by the underlying type of `M`, which
satisfy the relations of the Coxeter matrix `M`. -/
structure CoxeterSystem (W : Type u) [Group W]  where
  /-- `CoxeterSystem.ofMulEquiv` constructs a Coxeter system given an equivalence with the group
  presentation corresponding to a Coxeter matrix `M`. -/
  ofMulEquiv ::
    /-- `mulEquiv` is the isomorphism between the group `W` and the group presentation
    corresponding to a Coxeter matrix `M`. -/
    mulEquiv : Matrix.CoxeterGroup M ≃* W

/-- Coxeter system of type `M` on the group `M.CoxeterGroup`. -/
def Matrix.coxeterSystemCoxeterGroup : CoxeterSystem M M.CoxeterGroup :=
  CoxeterSystem.ofMulEquiv (MulEquiv.refl _)

/-- A group is a Coxeter group if it is registered in a Coxeter system
 for some Coxeter matrix `M`. -/
class IsCoxeterGroup (W : Type u) [Group W] : Prop where
  nonempty_system : ∃ (B : Type u), ∃ (M : Matrix B B ℕ),
    M.IsCoxeter ∧ Nonempty (CoxeterSystem M W)

namespace CoxeterSystem

variable {W : Type u} [Group W] [M.IsCoxeter]

/-- A group registered in a Coxeter system is a Coxeter group. -/
lemma isCoxeterGroup (cs : CoxeterSystem M W) : IsCoxeterGroup W where
  nonempty_system := ⟨B, M, ⟨by rename_i h; exact h, Nonempty.intro cs⟩⟩

instance : IsCoxeterGroup M.CoxeterGroup :=
  isCoxeterGroup M (Matrix.coxeterSystemCoxeterGroup M)

end CoxeterSystem
```

where to get this to work, for the lemma and instance in the `CoxeterSystem` namespace, I had to make sure to keep `B` and `W` in the same universe `u`.

In summary, I haven't been able to get code that works with `[M.IsCoxeter]` while using existential quantifiers in `IsCoxeterGroup`. Therefore, if this (`∃`) is something that is desired than the later example is probably the better route.  However, I must say it still leaves something to be desired with `Matrix.CoxeterGroup` since we could feed it junk.  

Thoughts?

I am very strongly in favor of your second proposal. There is just something fishy with universes -- there is no reason why `B` and `W` should be in the same universe. In the definition of `IsCoxeterGroup`, I would require `B` to be in `Type u`, as you do, but then I would prove a lemma saying that if you have a Coxeter system in `Type v`, then you can also build one in `Type u`, so that your group indeed satisfies `IsCoxeterGroup`. 

You can see how this is done for the free group in https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/blob/master/Mathlib/GroupTheory/FreeGroup/IsFreeGroup.lean, where the definition `IsFreeGroup` requires a basis in the same universe as the group, but the lemma `isFreeGroup` says that, if you have a basis in any universe, then your group satisfies `IsFreeGroup`.

Also, I would change your `abbrev` to a proper def -- which means you should register explicitly the group instance on it, as Lean will not be able to see through the definition. IMHO, it's not a problem if the definition doesn't require `[M.IsCoxeter]`: this assumption will just be put in the relevant theorems.

> I am very strongly in favor of your second proposal. There is just something fishy with universes -- there is no reason why `B` and `W` should be in the same universe. In the definition of `IsCoxeterGroup`, I would require `B` to be in `Type u`, as you do, but then I would prove a lemma saying that if you have a Coxeter system in `Type v`, then you can also build one in `Type u`, so that your group indeed satisfies `IsCoxeterGroup`.
> 
> You can see how this is done for the free group in https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/blob/master/Mathlib/GroupTheory/FreeGroup/IsFreeGroup.lean, where the definition `IsFreeGroup` requires a basis in the same universe as the group, but the lemma `isFreeGroup` says that, if you have a basis in any universe, then your group satisfies `IsFreeGroup`.

@sgouezel Okay, so I took a look at the link above and what you mentioned and started playing with trying to get it to work but having some issues following what you did.  I haven't figured out how to make it work with this extra *layer of matrix* that I have.  Nor how I would then show that this matrix must be `IsCoxeter`.  From what it seems I will need the signatures to be:

```
namespace CoxeterSystem

variable {B B' W : Type*} [Group W]

variable {M : Matrix B B ℕ} {M' : Matrix B' B' ℕ}

instance funLike : FunLike (CoxeterSystem M W) (Matrix B B ℕ) (fun _ => W) :=  sorry

protected def reindex (cs : CoxeterSystem M W) (e : Matrix B B ℕ ≃ Matrix B' B' ℕ) : 
        CoxeterSystem M' W := sorry

protected lemma injective (cs : CoxeterSystem M W) : Function.Injective cs := sorry

lemma isCoxeterGroup (cs : CoxeterSystem M W) : IsCoxeterGroup W :=
        ⟨Set.range cs, sorry, ⟨sorry, sorry⟩⟩

end CoxeterSystem
```

does this seem to be headed in the *general* direction?   I am not completely confident these signatures are the way they should be. For the signatures above, I am currently hung up on how to construct the matrix for the existential in `isCoxeterGroup` so if you have any advice on how to do that properly I am keen to hear it.

Instead of your `e`, I would use an equiv between `B` and `B'`. With this equiv, you can reindex your matrix `M : Matrix B B ℕ` to get a matrix `Matrix B' B' ℕ`, and this matrix will be Coxeter (it's a copy of the original matrix, after all!)

@sgouezel I finally got some time to work on this a bit again after being away.  I just pushed what I currently have but was hoping you could take a quick look and give me your opinion if you think the direction I am going seems okay?  I am mostly following what is done in `IsFreeGroup`.  One of the things I am uncertain of is how to show the map is injective.  When taking a look at how `FreeGroup.of_injective` does it, it seems like I should be able to do something similar since, in theory, `FreeGroup` is a `Quot` after all, but I am unfamiliar with the details still so this may be an ill assumption.  If you know of an easier way to prove this, I am all ears.  In regards to the other proof still left over I think using `QuotienGroup.congr` seems right(?) and still working through the details to show that there should be some map connecting the normal closures of the relations for `B` and `B'`.

It seems to me there are some missing lemmas about presented groups: the first thing to prove is that, if you have an equiv `e` between two types alpha and beta, and relations inside alpha, then the group they define is isomorphic to the group defined by these relations pushed by `e` in beta (and moreover the isomorphism, in some sense, lifts `e`). Does that make sense? Then what you need for Coxeter groups should be a particular case of this one.
This makes sense and hopefully I can find a proof for this when I get some more time to work on this in a couple weeks to push this PR over the line.  Thanks for the feedback!
This definition should rather be: there exists `B : Type`, there exists `M : Matrix B B ℕ`, such that `IsCoxeter M` and `Nonempty (CoxeterSystem M W)`.

If you look back in the commit history I had what you are stating except for the existential quantifier on `B`.  It was then suggested to me in a previous code review that we should be having `[M.IsCoxeter]` for the definitions, so that is why I moved things around.  What is the consensus from the reviewers on this?
No, I did the exact same suggestion as @sgouezel!

I was referring to the [`M.IsCoxeter]`.  I wasn't implying that you were not suggesting the same thing with `∃ B`, because you did suggest that as well.  I shouldn't have bundled the comments together as I did, since it caused some miscommunication on my part.
Why do you need `[NeZero n]` here and below?
I don't actually, I figured out a way to get past the errors for `Bₙ` and `Dₙ` by casting 1 to `(1 : ℕ)`.

Using `simp` on a type is pretty weird. I think you probably want
```suggestion
abbrev Matrix.CoxeterGroup := PresentedGroup <| CoxeterGroup.Relations.toSet M
```
@eric-wieser  A previous reviewer suggested I use `def` instead of `abbrev` but I will look at removing the `simp`.
Can you link to the discussion?
@eric-wieser  [here](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/8223#discussion_r1393752877)

```suggestion
    if i = j then 1
      else (if i = n - 1 ∨ j = n - 1 then 2 else 3)
```
(and throughout)

Minor nitpicks:
```suggestion
Coxeter group. The Coxeter group `W` is defined by the presentation
`W = ⟨s₁,s₂,...,sₙ | ∀ i j, (sᵢsⱼ)^mᵢⱼ = 1⟩`, where `1` is the identity element of `W`.
```
Or maybe 'A Coxeter group' ...? Also, is it 'defined' or 'determined' by the presentation?
I like 'A Coxeter group' and I would agree that using 'determined' is more accurate since a presentation is not unique.  I like being as correct as possible so thanks for the nits!

```suggestion
instance : Group (Matrix.CoxeterGroup M) :=
  QuotientGroup.Quotient.group _
```
The current order of variables seems to be `M W`. Is that intentional? I would have expected `W M`, I think.

I was just allowing lean to set this since I am not passing in `M` explicitly here.  Also, since `M` is associated with the relations I would think it is more *natural* for it to come before the group that is generated by these relations (but maybe my thinking is backwards here?)

Out of curiosity, why would have you expected `W M`?
In analyogy with the `(W,S)` that you often see in the literature for Coxeter groups. But it's not very important, so feel free to keep `M W`.

Untested, but I guess this should work
```suggestion
def Matrix.coxeterSystemCoxeterGroup : CoxeterSystem M M.CoxeterGroup where
  mulEquiv := .refl _
```

```suggestion
/-- A group is a Coxeter group if it admits a Coxeter system
 for some Coxeter matrix `M`. -/
```
All the `.symm`s suggest flipping the direction of the `MulEquiv` in the definition above. But I have not yet read the rest of the file, so I don't know what the optimal direction is.
This is a good question.  For context, I followed the direction of `FreeGroupBasis` in `Mathlib.GroupTheory.FreeGroup.IsFreeGroup`.
Ok, let's keep it like this for now. But I can imagine we might want to flip later (maybe in both places).

```suggestion
  cs.mulEquiv.eq_symm_apply.mp rfl
```
Isn't this a duplicate of `Matrix.coxeterSystemCoxeterGroup`?
Yes it is, I am going to remove the former (while keeping your change from there)

```suggestion
@[simps]
def equivCoxeterGroup (e : B ≃ B') : CoxeterGroup M ≃* CoxeterGroup (reindex e e M) :=
```
Hopefully this will autogenerate the simp-lemmas below.

~~It wants @[simps!] so will use that.~~

Actually, this causes linting to fail:

```
$ lake exe runLinter Mathlib.GroupTheory.SpecificGroups.Coxeter
-- Found 2 errors in 41255 declarations (plus 100127 automatically generated ones) in Mathlib.GroupTheory.SpecificGroups.Coxeter with 14 linters

/- The `simpNF` linter reports:
SOME SIMP LEMMAS ARE NOT IN SIMP-NORMAL FORM.
see note [simp-normal form] for tips how to debug this.
https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib_docs/notes.html#simp-normal%20form -/

  (CoxeterSystem.equivCoxeterGroup e) a
to
  (CoxeterSystem.equivCoxeterGroup e) a
using
  simp only [@Matrix.reindex_apply]
Try to change the left-hand side to the simplified term!

./././Mathlib/GroupTheory/SpecificGroups/Coxeter.lean:207:3: error: CoxeterSystem.equivCoxeterGroup_symm_apply.{u_3, u_2} Left-hand side simplifies from
  (MulEquiv.symm (CoxeterSystem.equivCoxeterGroup e)) a
to
  (MulEquiv.symm (CoxeterSystem.equivCoxeterGroup e)) a
using
  simp only [@Matrix.reindex_apply]
Try to change the left-hand side to the simplified term!

```

```suggestion
@[simps]
protected def reindex (cs : CoxeterSystem M W) (e : B ≃ B') :
```
Idem

```suggestion
@[simps]
protected def map (cs : CoxeterSystem M W) (e : W ≃* H) : CoxeterSystem M H :=
```

This classification is not part of this PR, so I suggest
```suggestion
The finite Coxeter groups are classified (TODO) as the four infinite families:

* `Aₙ, Bₙ, Dₙ, I₂ₘ`

And the exceptional systems:

* `E₆, E₇, E₈, F₄, G₂, H₃, H₄`
```

```suggestion
In this file a Coxeter system, designated as `CoxeterSystem M W`, is implemented as a
structure which effectively records the isomorphism between a group `W` and the corresponding
group presentation derived from a Coxeter matrix `M`.  From another perspective, it serves as a
```

```suggestion
/-- The map sending a Coxeter system to its associated map `B → W` is injective. -/
```

Could you double check the definition of all the matrices, because it seems to me that some of these are wrong. For example, for $A_n$, the coefficient $(i,j)$ for i different from $j$ is either $3$ when $j = i\pm 1$ and $2$ otherwise?
I updated the definitions for the infinite families.  I *think* they are correct now but please take another look if you can.
Is there a reason this is a `class` and not a `structure`? If so, can you add it to the docstring?
Not that I know and I actually don't see too many future places where this would be needed (Lean's type inference system) so will change it to a structure.
This should be correct, but in mathlib, we try to refrain using the difference of natural numbers. Instead of `i - j = 1`, I think that `(j : ℕ) + 1 = i` would be a better phrasing of this condition.
This is not natural subtraction, but `Fin` (wraparound) subtraction; so when `n = 4`, `0 - 3 = 1` is true, which is possibly not what is needed here
Ah yes, `Fin n` wraps.  I updated with typecasts to the integers.  Hopefully this is correct now.
I still think `(j : ℕ) + 1 = i` is a better phrasing.

> I still think `(j : ℕ) + 1 = i` is a better phrasing.

At first I didn't really see the big difference but since it is possible to keep it within the natural numbers without coercion to the integers, might as well (since Fin n seems closer to N than Z).  If there are any other good reasons to do it this way over coercion to the integers (well the code is shorter as well which is nicer), please let me know as I am curious.  Branch has been updated.

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat(GroupTheory/SpecificGroups/Coxeter) : Add Coxeter Systems and Coxeter Groups

nodes.body:
In the basic API for Coxeter systems, I would think you could include this lemma:
```lean
@[simp]
lemma apply_mul_apply_pow (cs : CoxeterSystem M W) (b₁ b₂ : B) :
    (cs b₁ * cs b₂) ^ M b₁ b₂ = 1 := sorry
```

> In the basic API for Coxeter systems, I would think you could include this lemma:
> 
> ```lean
> @[simp]
> lemma apply_mul_apply_pow (cs : CoxeterSystem M W) (b₁ b₂ : B) :
>     (cs b₁ * cs b₂) ^ M b₁ b₂ = 1 := sorry
> ```

As the current PR is already getting rather large I would like to focus on getting what I have into Mathlib and then can add this in a future PR.

Besides my one comment on the module docstring, I think this looks good now.

So I suggest we merge this, and then more stuff can be done in follow-ups :smile: 

bors d+

Thanks to all the reviewers that helped me with this PR!  Your guidance is greatly appreciated!
